snippet: Wall to Wall, an annual daylong tribute at Symphony Space, was devoted to Gertrude Stein and her musical and literary circle.
lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years now Symphony Space has set aside a day to focus at length on a specific composer, artist, era or theme: Wall to Wall, the enduring marathon concept that started with a daylong Bach concert in 1978. In most of these events it can seem as if Symphony Space were attempting to cram an entire voluminous world into 12 hours on a single stage, to varying if nearly always edifying effect. This year's installment, ''Wall to Wall Gertrude's Paris,'' presented on Saturday, felt different: more open, yet, paradoxically, unusually focused. To start with, the event, assembled by Laura Kaminsky, a composer and the Symphony Space artistic director, took its lead from another institution's doings: ''The Steins Collect: Matisse, Picasso and the Parisian Avant-Garde,'' a collection now on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline.main: Convening a Salon for Gertrude Stein and Friends
